abstract.p: Plants constantly monitor their environment to adapt to potential threats to their health and fitness. This involves cell-surface receptors that can detect conserved microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) or endogenous immunogenic signals, initiating signaling pathways to induce broad-spectrum disease resistance, known as pattern-triggered immunity (PTI). In Arabidopsis thaliana, the leucine-rich repeat receptor kinase (LRR-RK) MIK2 is an exceptionally versatile receptor involved in the perception of the vast family of Brassicales-specific endogenous SCOOP peptides as well as potential MAMPs derived from Fusarium and related fungi. Although only plant species belonging to the order of Brassicales encode genes for SCOOP peptides and show SCOOP-responsiveness, the Fusarium-derived elicitor fraction also induces PTI responses in plants from other lineages. In this study, we demonstrate that Fusarium elicitor-responsiveness and proteins belonging to the MIK2-clade are widely conserved among seed plants. We identified a MIK2-clade protein from tomato, which shares properties of AtMIK2 in the perception of the Fusarium elicitor but not of SCOOP peptides. Tomato mutants lacking the receptor show compromised PTI responses to the fungal elicitor and enhanced susceptibility to infection by Fusarium oxysporum. Our data provide insights into the evolutionary trajectory of MIK2 as a multifunctional receptor involved in plant immunity.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: To respond appropriately to changes in their environment and potential dangers, plants require the ability to sense and transmit signals coming from their surroundings. A major threat to plant fitness and survival is posed by pathogenic microbes or other pests. Therefore, plants constantly monitor their environment with membrane-localized pattern recognition receptors (PRRs). PRRs are receptor kinases (RKs) or receptor proteins (RPs) that evolved to recognize conserved molecules of microbial origin. Collectively, these molecular signatures are referred to as microbe-associated molecular patterns (MAMPs) (Boller and Felix, 2009; Basu et al., 2018). In addition, specialized receptors detect plant-derived danger signals, known as damage-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Those primary endogenous danger signals are passively released by injury or destruction caused by invading pathogens or other pests. In addition, so-called secondary endogenous danger signals are actively processed and released after tissue damage or other stimuli. Due to similarities to metazoan cytokines, secondary danger molecules are also commonly referred to as phytocytokines (Gust et al., 2017).

After ligand-perception by PRRs, the signal feeds into a conserved signaling pathway to induce broad-spectrum disease-resistance, known as pattern-triggered immunity (PTI) (Jones and Dangl, 2006; Boller and He, 2009). In the case of proteinaceous ligands, PRRs belonging to the class of leucine-rich repeat receptor kinases (LRR-RKs) readily recruit co-receptors of the SOMATIC EMBRYOGENESIS RECEPTOR-LIKE KINASE (SERK) family, including BRI1-ASSOCIATED RECEPTOR KINASE 1 (BAK1) or BAK1-LIKE 1 (BKK1) in a ligand-dependent manner to form activated receptor-complexes (DeFalco and Zipfel, 2021). In addition, receptor-like cytoplasmic kinases (RLCKs) such as BOTRYTIS-INDUCED KINASE 1 (BIK1) and PBS1-LIKE 1 (PBL1) constitutively associate with the cytoplasmic region of the PRR-complexes (Hailemariam et al., 2024). Upon ligand-perception and receptor-activation, the signal is transduced to the cytoplasm where an array of immune-signaling events is induced. Following the activation and release of RLCKs from the receptor-complex, plants initiate the rapid and transient elevation of cytoplasmic free-calcium concentration [Ca2+]cyt, the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the apoplast and the phosphorylation-dependent activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK)-cascades (Köster et al., 2022; Sun and Zhang, 2022; Wu et al., 2023). Through the activation of transcriptional regulators, including transcription factors (TFs) and chromatin modifiers, extensive transcriptional reprogramming is initiated (Bigeard et al., 2015; Li et al., 2016). Assisted by posttranscriptional, epigenetic and posttranslational regulators, the transcriptional reprogramming culminates in a broad array of defense responses (Li et al., 2016; Withers and Dong, 2017; Tao et al., 2023). Those include the synthesis and emission of phytohormones like ethylene, the biosynthesis and secretion of antimicrobial compounds like phytoalexins as well as the reinforcement of plant cell walls by the deposition of lignin and callose (Hückelhoven, 2007; Ahuja et al., 2012; Bednarek, 2012; Zipfel, 2013).

PTI signaling is tightly controlled by both negative and positive feedback mechanisms, to enhance weak or attenuate overshooting immune responses. One of those mechanisms is also mediated by membrane-localized receptors that perceive the aforementioned phytocytokines. These endogenous peptides can be actively released by enzymatic processing, regulate intercellular signaling and can function simultaneously in growth and development as well as in immunity, positioning them as key players in the growth-defense trade-off (Rzemieniewski and Stegmann, 2022).

In most cases, plant PRRs and receptors for phytocytokines are restricted to the perception of either exogenous or endogenous signals. However, there are very few exceptions, like the NEMATODE-INDUCED LRR-RLK 1 (NILR1) receptor from Solanum tuberosum (potato), which perceives both the exogenous nematode-associated molecular pattern (NAMP) ascaroside and the endogenous plant hormone brassinosteroid (Huang et al., 2024; Huang et al., 2023, 2023; Huang et al., 2024). Another example for a receptor with dual ligands is MALE DISCOVERER 1-INTERACTING RECEPTOR-LIKE KINASE 2 (MIK2) from Arabidopsis thaliana. MIK2 is the receptor for the extensive family of SERINE-RICH ENDOGENOUS PEPTIDEs (SCOOPs), which are specific to the order of Brassicales, with 50 members in A. thaliana alone (Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021; Snoeck et al., 2024; Yang et al., 2023a). Aside a conserved SxS motif, which is found in the large majority of SCOOPs, the amino acid sequences of the individual peptides are highly variable (Gully et al., 2019; Snoeck et al., 2024; Yang et al., 2023a). Most recently, AI-assisted structural modeling coupled with phylogenomics revealed that the highly conserved SxS motif mediates binding to MIK2 (Snoeck et al., 2024). This was then supported by crystallography and cryoEM structural studies, which also indicated that MIK2 N-glycosylation facilitates its interaction with the co-receptor BAK1 (Jia et al., 2024; Wu et al., 2024).

In addition to the perception of the large and diverse set of SCOOPs, MIK2 is also indispensable for PTI responses triggered by a proteinaceous elicitor found in extracts of diverse Fusarium and related fungal species (Coleman et al., 2021), consistent with MIK2’s role in basal resistance against Fusarium oxysporum (van der Does et al., 2017). Even though the true nature of the fungal elicitor is yet to be revealed, bioinformatics approaches have identified SCOOP-LIKE (SCOOPL) peptide sequences as epitopes within different Fusarium proteins. When synthesized based on the characteristics of major plant SCOOPs, those SCOOPL peptides also triggered PTI responses in Arabidopsis thaliana (Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021). However, most of the proposed SCOOPL peptide sequences are hardly conserved beyond the fungal genus Fusarium, while comparable MIK2-dependent elicitor activity could also be found in extracts from the related fungal genus Trichoderma (Coleman et al., 2021). Additionally, the Fusarium elicitor triggers PTI-like responses in various non-Brassicales plant species, including soybean, tomato and barley, while the perception of SCOOP and SCOOPL peptides is restricted to the order of Brassicales (Coleman et al., 2021; Snoeck et al., 2024).

Here we report about an LRR-RK from tomato with phylogenetic origin common to Arabidopsis thaliana MIK2 (AtMIK2). This tomato protein belonging to the MIK2-clade shares functions of AtMIK2 in response to the Fusarium elicitor and resistance to Fusarium infection, but not in perception of plant SCOOPs or synthetic Fusarium SCOOPL peptides, thus suggesting that the Brassicales-specific function of MIK2 as a SCOOP receptor has arisen from a more ancient function as a PRR for a Fusarium-derived MAMP.

sec.title: Fusarium elicitor-responsiveness and proteins of the MIK2-clade are conserved among different plant families
sec.p: Bioinformatics approaches already identified SCOOP-LIKE peptide sequences embedded in proteins of Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. conglutinans isolate Fo5176 (FocSCOOPL) that show AtMIK2-dependent immunogenic activity in Arabidopsis thaliana. We first wanted to test whether predicted fungal SCOOPL peptides share elicitor activity with the enriched elicitor fraction generated from mycelial extracts of the fungal pathogen Fusarium oxysporum (EnFOE), outside the order of Brassicales. Similar to AtSCOOP12, the FocSCOOPLFOXB_11846 (Wu et al., 2024) and FocSCOOPLF9F6H0 (Rhodes et al., 2021) peptides only triggered the accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) in Arabidopsis thaliana and Brassica rapa, while species like soybean (Glycine max), tomato (Solanum lycopersicum) and barley (Hordeum vulgare) did not respond to treatment with either of these peptides (fig. 1b-d). In contrast, treatment with EnFOE triggered a transient ROS burst also in most of the tested non-Brassicales plant species (fig. 1a). Interestingly, the solanaceous species Nicotiana benthamiana is unresponsive to AtSCOOP12, FocSCOOPLs as well as EnFOE, but, like all other plant species tested, responds to treatment with flg22 and chitin (fig. 1a-d; fig. S1a-b). This raises the possibility that EnFOE-induced ROS production in some non-Brassicales plant species is triggered by immunogenic patterns of a different nature than the proposed SCOOPL Fusarium peptides.

Differences in the responsiveness to the Fusarium elicitor and SCOOP/SCOOPL peptides in different plants motivated us to look for putative orthologues of AtMIK2 in diverse plant families, which might share its role in the perception of the Fusarium elicitor, but have not evolved to recognize SCOOPs. Hence, we searched for proteins with structural and phylogenetic relation to AtMIK2 outside the order of Brassicales. A phylogenetic analysis including representatives of major angiosperm lineages and Ginkgo (a gymnosperm) revealed that genes of the MIK2-clade are evolutionarily conserved in seed plants (100% support), but could not be identified in bryophytes, lycophytes and monilophytes (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). A duplication event in a common ancestor of monocots, dicots and water lilies gave rise to the MIK2-clade as sister to the MIK2-sister-clade (94% support), while only the latter contains two sequences of the basic angiosperm Amborella trichopoda (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). Both clades harbor representatives of the orders of Poales, Solanales, Brassicales and Fabales. Within the MIK2-clade, several duplication events occurred, e.g. between one and two at the root of dicots (81% and 41% support). However, most retained gene duplications appear at family- or even species-level (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). Lower gene copy numbers indicate that MIK2-sister-clade genes are largely purged after duplication events and are even completely lost in most species belonging to the Brassicales (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). In contrast, we observed that MIK2-clade genes are more often retained. We counted between four (chickpea) and twenty-three (peanut) copies in Fabales, between five (tomato) and eleven (potato) copies in Solanales and in grasses from one in rice up to seventeen copies in barley (fig. 1f, fig. S1c). Due to relatively low annotation certainty of the Solanales plants Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana tabacum and wild tomato Solanum chilense, those species were only included in the phylogenetic tree, but we cannot make statements on actual copy numbers (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c).

Interestingly, Brassicales members tend to retain fewer copies, ranging between one in Schrenkiella parvula and six in Capsella rubella, than other Rosids and Asterids like potato with eleven copies or sunflower with fourteen copies (fig. 1f; fig. S1c). We identified five MIK2-clade genes in tomato, while Arabidopsis thaliana exhibits two copies, MIK2 (AT4G08850) and MIK2-LIKE (AT1G35710), as a result of a brassica-specific duplication (100% support). A duplication specific to Fabales (100% support) followed by several lineage specific duplications resulted in twenty maintained genes in Glycine max (fig. 1f; fig. S1c). In summary, genes of the MIK2-clade are evolutionarily conserved in seed plants and show a highly species-dependent pattern of gene duplication and retention.

sec.title: A MIK2-clade protein from Solanum lycopersicum shows similar properties to AtMIK2 in Fusarium elicitor perception
sec.p: To continue our search for putative orthologues of AtMIK2 in the perception of the Fusarium elicitor, we decided to further investigate the MIK2-clade proteins identified in Solanum lycopersicum, a plant species that is commonly affected by Fusarium infections (McGovern, 2015). For this purpose, we cloned the five tomato MIK2-clade genes as well as the gene from the MIK2-sister-clade, which we have designated as SlMIK2-A to -E and SlMIK2-SISTER, respectively (fig. 2a). Subsequently, we transiently expressed the proteins in Nicotiana benthamiana, which naturally does not respond to EnFOE- or SCOOP-treatment (fig. 1a-d). Since this approach has proven successful for AtMIK2 (Coleman et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021), we included the wildtype and a kinase-dead version (AtMIK2^km, K802A) of the protein as positive and negative controls. All proteins tested expressed in Nicotiana benthamiana, even though SlMIK2-E expressed to a lower degree when compared to the others (fig. S2c).

Similar to what was reported before, leaf discs from Nicotiana benthamiana transiently over-expressing AtMIK2 showed a clear ROS-burst when treated with AtSCOOP12. By contrast, this was not the case when leaves expressed AtMIK2^km or either of the SlMIK2 or SlMIK2-SISTER proteins, where no AtSCOOP12-induced ROS accumulation could be detected (fig. 2c). Similarly, treatment with the FocSCOOPL peptides induced ROS production only if leaves were expressing the wildtype version of AtMIK2 (fig. S2a-b). In contrast, treatment with EnFOE did not only induce ROS accumulation in leaves transformed with wildtype AtMIK2, but also transient expression of the SlMIK2-A protein conferred EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana, whereas this could not be observed for any of the other tomato proteins tested (fig. 2b). These results suggest that SlMIK2-A might serve a function comparable to that of AtMIK2 in perception of EnFOE, but not of AtSCOOP or FocSCOOPL peptides.

Additional evidence for a probable common evolutionary origin of AtMIK2 and genes belonging to the tomato MIK2-clade was gathered through a synteny analysis. This revealed that a conserved genomic region harbors AtMIK2 and four of the tomato MIK2-clade genes in the respective plant species (fig. 2d). While SlMIK2-B to -D reside in tandem on the minus strand, SlMIK2-A is located on the plus strand and separated from the others by an unrelated gene (fig. 2d).

With a 1048-amino acid long protein sequence and a predicted LRR-RK structure containing 25 LRRs, the SlMIK2-A protein shows 48% identity and 65% similarity to the sequence of AtMIK2 (1045 amino acids, 24 LRRs). Interestingly, SlMIK2-A is predicted to be spliced into four different variants (fig. 2e). This might be the reason for the characteristic double-band observed on the western blot, since the C-terminal Myc-tag would allow the detection of the three splice-variants that share the same C-terminus (fig. 2e, 2g; fig. S2c). Even though the protein resulting from splice-variant 1 is the most similar to AtMIK2, we have cloned all four splice-variants individually, either by removal of the additional introns in the region coding for the extracellular domain (splice-variants 2 & 4), shortening and changing the C-terminal sequence coding for the cytoplasmic-domain (splice-variant 3), or mutation of splice-sites (splice-variant 1).

The individual splice-variants were transiently over-expressed in Nicotiana benthamiana, alongside the unmodified (genomic) and a kinase-dead version of SlMIK2-A (^km, K791A), as well as AtMIK2 and AtMIK2^km (fig. 2g). Only splice-variant 1 conferred EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana comparable to AtMIK2 and SlMIK2-A when expressed through its genomic sequence (fig. 2f). None of the individually expressed splice-variants were able to confer AtSCOOP12-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. S2d). As is the case for AtMIK2, SlMIK2-A requires a functional kinase domain to confer EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. 2f). Through RT-qPCR analysis with splice-variant-specific primers, we identified that transcripts of splice-variant 1 are the most abundant in tomato wildtype plants. While splice-variants 2 and 4 are on average 74% and 55% less abundant than splice-variants 1, expression of splice-variant 3 was barely detectable (fig. S2e). In summary, the most abundantly transcribed splice-variant of SlMIK2-A is also the only one translated into a protein that can confer EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana. The expression of this splice-variant was also induced 2 hours after treatment with EnFOE or chitin in whole plants and 21 days after infection with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici (strain Fol007) in shoot stems (fig. 2h).

Similar to what has been observed for AtMIK2 (van der Does et al. 2017), also SlMIK2-A (splice-variant 1) seemingly localizes to the plasma membrane (fig. 2i-j). We transiently co-expressed AtMIK2-GFP and SlMIK2-A-mCherry in Nicotiana benthamiana and imaged with confocal microscopy 36 hours after infiltration (fig. 2i). Measurement of the fluorescence intensity along the indicated ROI line show an overlap of GFP- and mCherry-signals at the cell periphery (fig. 2j).

sec.title: SlMIK2-A forms ligand-induced complexes with tomato BAK1 orthologues and depletes elicitor-activity from EnFOE
sec.p: Since AtMIK2 has previously been shown to form ligand-induced complexes with the common co-receptor AtBAK1 after treatment with EnFOE, AtSCOOPs and Fusarium SCOOPL peptides (Coleman et al., 2021; Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021), we tested whether similar complexes are induced between their tomato counterparts. Tomato has two proteins with a high sequence similarity to AtBAK1, termed SlSERK3a and SlSERK3b, both of which have been implicated to function in plant innate immunity (Mantelin et al., 2011; Peng and Kaloshian, 2014). We tested ligand-induced complex formation between SlMIK2-A and both tomato BAK1 orthologues in co-immunoprecipitation (CoIP) experiments using transient expression in Nicotiana benthamiana. The receptor pair from Arabidopsis thaliana was used as positive control, while SlMIK2-B, which does not seem to be involved in the perception of EnFOE (fig. 2 b), was included as negative control.

Reflecting previous results from the gain-of-function assay (fig. 2c; fig. S2a), treatment with AtSCOOP12 and the FocSCOOPLFOXB_11846 peptide induced a ligand-induced complex between AtMIK2 and AtBAK1, while no clear interaction between any of the tomato proteins could be observed (fig. 3b, S3a). In contrast, EnFOE-treatment induced complex formation between AtMIK2 and AtBAK1 but also triggered the interaction of SlMIK2-A with either SlSERK3a or SlSERK3b (fig. 3a). However, EnFOE did not induce association between SlMIK2-B and either of the tomato BAK1 orthologues (fig. 3a). These results suggest a conserved perception mechanism of the Fusarium elicitor in Arabidopsis thaliana and Solanum lycopersicum.

Since the results from the CoIP experiments indicate interaction between an elicitor-active molecule in EnFOE and the ectodomain of AtMIK2 as well as SlMIK2-A, we sought for a way to further substantiate this supposition. For this purpose, we adopted a so-called ligand depletion assay (Shu et al., 2021) (fig. 3c). We expressed affinity-tagged ectodomains (N-terminal TwinStrep tag) of different LRR-RKs in Nicotiana benthamiana and collected them with apoplastic wash fluids (AWFs). We subsequently coupled the tagged ectodomains to affinity columns, while other apoplastic molecules were washed out. We then run preparations containing our elicitor activity through the ectodomain-lined columns and subsequently analyzed the flow-through for depletion of the ligands. Since all our ligands of interest induce a transient elevation of cytosolic-free calcium concentrations [Ca2+]cyt, we checked for remaining elicitor activity with a highly sensitive Ca2+ bioassay using apoaequorin-expressing Arabidopsis thaliana Columbia-0 wildtype (Col-0AEQ) and mik2AEQ mutants generated in the same genetic background via CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knock-out (fig. S3c).

The ectodomains of both AtMIK2 (eAtMIK2) and SlMIK2-A (eSlMIK2-A) expressed to a satisfying degree in Nicotiana benthamiana. As controls, we have additionally expressed the ectodomains of Arabidopsis thaliana CLAVATA1 (eAtCLV1) and SlMIK2-B (eSlMIK2-B), both of which are not assumed to interact with any of our ligands of interest. As expected, preparations containing AtSCOOP12 [25 nM], that were run through columns lined with the ectodomains of its bona fide receptor AtMIK2, were depleted from elicitor activity and triggered no calcium transient distinguishable between Col-0AEQ wildtype and mik2AEQ mutant seedlings (fig. 3e). In contrast, the same preparations that were run through columns lined with eAtCLV1, induced a clear MIK2-dependent calcium-response in Col-0AEQ seedlings (fig. 3e). The same is true for both eSlMIK2-A and eSlMIK2-B, where neither of the ectodomains were able to deplete AtSCOOP12 activity from the preparations (fig. 3e). AtSCOOP12 activity was hence specifically depleted by AtMIK2 ectodomains but not by any other LRR ectodomain tested.

We then used the same set-up for the EnFOE preparations. Similar to AtSCOOP12, columns lined with AtMIK2 fully depleted the elicitor activity from EnFOE, while preparations filtered through eAtCLV1-lined columns retained the ability to induce an AtMIK2-dependent calcium transient in Col-0AEQ wildtype seedlings (fig. 3d). Columns lined with the ectodomain of SlMIK2-A also depleted EnFOE preparations from elicitor activity, and the respective flow-through did not trigger a calcium response in wildtype seedlings that significantly exceeded that of the mik2AEQ mutants. Preparations filtered through the columns lined with eSlMIK2-B still harbored AtMIK2-dependent elicitor activity (fig. 3d). The ectodomain of tomato SlMIK2-A could hence specifically deplete the elicitor activity from EnFOE that is perceived AtMIK2-dependently in Arabidopsis thaliana. This suggests that ectodomains of AtMIK2 and SlMIK2-A have affinity to the same elicitor activity in EnFOE. Neither of the ectodomains tested could deplete the control peptide flg22, where all unbound fractions still harbored comparable AtFLS2-dependent elicitor activity (fig. 3f). To confirm approximately equal amounts of purified ectodomains used in each assay, proteins were subsequently eluted from the columns and visualized by western blot analysis (fig. S3b).

Taken together, these results further substantiate the proposed dual role of AtMIK2 both in the perception of endogenous SCOOP peptides and the exogenous Fusarium elicitor, while the phylogenetically related SlMIK2-A protein exclusively interacts with EnFOE-contained elicitor activity and has not evolved to participate in the perception of SCOOPs.

sec.title: SlMIK2-A is important for EnFOE-induced PTI responses and resistance against Fusarium oxysporum infection in tomato
sec.p: To confirm the role of SlMIK2-A in EnFOE-induced PTI responses in the native system, we generated two independent CRISPR/Cas9-mediated knock-out mutants in tomato. Both Slmik2-ACRISPR lines have homozygous frame-shift mutations within the first 500 base pairs (bp) of the coding sequence, introducing premature stopcodons and affecting all 4 possible splice-variants (fig. S3d). The corresponding wildtype control was transformed with a control construct (lacking the sequences of the guide RNAs) and has undergone tissue culture alongside the CRISPR mutants (azygous wildtype control). T-DNAs were segregated out in subsequent generations.

We first tested the tomato mutants for ROS production after elicitor treatment. When treated with EnFOE, both Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants showed a significantly reduced EnFOE-induced accumulation of ROS when compared to the azygous wildtype control (fig. 4a). However, ROS production in response to the fungal elicitor chitin was not altered by mutation of SlMIK2-A, since the wildtype and both mutant lines responded to a comparable degree (fig. 4b). Similarly, the EnFOE-induced accumulation of the phytohormone ethylene was significantly lower in the CRISPR mutants when compared to the corresponding wildtype control (fig. 4c). Interestingly, both mutants also showed a reduced chitin-induced ethylene accumulation when compared to the wildtype, which was significantly lower in line #2. Notably, even wildtype plants required relatively high concentrations of chitin (500 μg/mL) for the induction of a measurable accumulation of ethylene (fig. 4d). However, ethylene production in response to flg22 was on similar levels between all three plant lines tested (fig. 4e), indicating that the mutants do not have a general impairment in MAMP-induced ethylene accumulation. Taken together, similar to AtMIK2 in Arabidopsis thaliana, loss of SlMIK2-A in tomato leads to reduced sensitivity to treatment with EnFOE.

Finally, we wanted to see whether the loss of SlMIK2-A has an influence on the susceptibility of tomato towards infection with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici. We inoculated 2-week-old seedlings with the spores of the fungal isolates Fol007 via root-dip infection (Mes et al., 1999). Growth parameters of infected plants (fresh-weight, plant height) were assessed 3 weeks post infection and calculated relative to those of mock-treated plants. On average, Fol007-infected azygous wildtype control plants showed around 8% reduction of fresh-weight compared to mock-treated plants, while the impact on both Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants was significantly higher, with reductions of around 21% on average (fig. 4f, left panel). Similarly, also reductions of plant height in the mutants averaged around 21% and were significantly higher than those observed in the wildtype control plants, which on average showed a reduction of around 12% (fig. 4g, left panel). Nevertheless, general fresh-weight and plant height of mock-treated plants were not significantly different between wildtype control and either of the mutant lines (fig. 4f-g, right panels). In summary, loss of SlMIK2-A does not generally impact growth parameters like fresh-weight and plant height in uninfected tomato plants. However, infection with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici strain Fol007 has a significantly higher negative impact on Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants than on the corresponding azygous wildtype control.

sec.title: Fusarium elicitor-responsiveness and proteins of the MIK2-clade are conserved among different plant families
sec.p: The Arabidopsis thaliana AtMIK2 receptor is an interesting example of a PRR that is involved in the perception and integration of both endogenous and exogenous peptide signals. Most of the previously reported phenotypes of Atmik2 mutants, including reduced salt-stress tolerance (Julkowska et al., 2016; van der Does et al., 2017), compromised responses to cell wall damage (van der Does et al., 2017) and enhanced susceptibility to herbivory (Stahl et al., 2022) could be directly or indirectly linked to its role as receptor for the large family of endogenous SCOOP peptides (Yang et al., 2023a; Zhai et al., 2024). In contrast, the elevated susceptibility to Fusarium oxysporum infection caused by loss of AtMIK2 (van der Does et al., 2017; Coleman et al., 2021) could not necessarily be attributed to the SCOOP-MIK2 signaling module (Yang et al., 2023a). These findings further support a SCOOP-independent role of AtMIK2 in the perception of an exogenous signal coming from Fusarium fungi. Peptide motifs with similarity to SCOOPs can be found embedded in various Fusarium proteins. When synthesized according to the predicted characteristics of plant SCOOPs, which are 13 amino acids in length and do not have posttranslational modifications, also the SCOOP-LIKE (SCOOPL) peptides from Fusarium induce PTI responses in Arabidopsis thaliana reminiscent of those induced by the plant endogenous peptides (Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021). SCOOP peptides are, however, only encoded in genomes of plant species belonging to the order Brassicales, and only members of this plant order show responsiveness to SCOOPs (Gully et al., 2019; Snoeck et al., 2024). Similarly, the synthetic SCOOPL peptides do not trigger any responses in non-Brassicales plant species (fig. 1b-d). In contrast, EnFOE does not only induce responses in Arabidopsis thaliana and related species, but also in plants from other plant lineages like soybean, tomato and barley (Coleman et al., 2021) (fig. 1a). These findings could suggest that said other plant species might be responsive to additional elicitor active molecules in EnFOE, which are not perceived by Arabidopsis thaliana. However, it is also conceivable that the SCOOPL peptides identified so far are not responsible for MIK2-dependent elicitor activity observed in EnFOE, at least not in their bioinformatically predicted and synthetic form. Even the reported peptide sequences of plant SCOOPs are still mainly based on bioinformatic predictions and could deviate significantly in their natural appearance and function, as recently suggested for AtSCOOP10 (Guillou et al., 2022). Variations in the sequence of peptide elicitors can lead to loss of recognition by certain plant species, while others are able to tolerate shorter minimal motifs. This has for example been demonstrated for bacterial flagellin, where the flg22 epitope is perceived by Arabidopsis thaliana and tomato, while the shorter flg15 motif only triggers responses in tomato (Felix et al., 1999). Another example of divergent perception requirements on the same elicitor by different plant species has been shown for SCP (small cysteine-rich protein) from Sclerotinia sclerotiorum. While perception by Arabidopsis thaliana depends on the tertiary structure of the SCP, closely related Brassicaceae species also perceive the SCP fragments in their linear form (Yang et al., 2023b). To conclusively verify the true identity and characteristics of the elicitor active molecule in EnFOE, the current bioinformatic efforts should additionally be supported by biochemical approaches in the future.

Even though MIK2 in its role as SCOOP receptor has been demonstrated to be conserved only within the order Brassicales (Snoeck et al., 2024), our phylogenetic analysis revealed that genes of the MIK2-clade are evolutionarily conserved in seed plants and display a highly family- and even species-dependent pattern of duplication and retention (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). This might have been driven by different environmental conditions and pathogen pressures encountered by different plant species over the course of evolution. Neo-functionalization and retention of duplicated receptors, for example by obtaining new ligand-specificities to recognize additional microbial signatures, might have been advantageous in specific locations and during times of high pathogen pressure. Such receptors could have become obsolete and subsequently been lost once plants managed to avoid certain pathogens by different means, for example via the adaptation to new environmental conditions that are not favorable for these microbes. This could have for example been the case for the herbivore-associated molecular pattern (HAMP) receptor INR, which is specific to the clade of Phaseoloid legumes and has been independently lost in some of the species (Snoeck et al., 2022). Even though it is common knowledge that classical MAMPs are usually highly conserved microbial structures that are not easily altered by the pathogens (Boller and Felix, 2009; Couto and Zipfel, 2016; Ranf, 2017), this must not necessarily be the case for every MAMP in a newly evolved ligand-receptor relation. It is conceivable that quite a few novel interactions are readily lost again due to insufficient conservation of the ligand and only good matches lead to the manifestation of a lasting ligand-receptor relation and subsequently the retention of the receptor. Even the prominent flg22 epitope, although considered highly conserved, has polymorphic sequences in certain bacteria that managed to evade immune-detection by most plant species (Fürst et al., 2020; Wei et al., 2020). Interestingly, members of Brassicales seem to retain fewer MIK2-clade gene copies compared to species belonging to other plant orders (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c). This could be related to their gained ability to perceive SCOOP peptides and hence their involvement in various biological processes. A duplication might lead to an imbalance in multiple, usually finely tuned signaling pathways and hence not be readily retained.

Surprisingly, in contrast to other plant species tested, Nicotiana benthamiana is unresponsive to treatment with EnFOE. Whether this exemption is due to the lack of a suitable MIK2-clade protein cannot be finally demonstrated, since the available genomic data is incompletely annotated. Even though two N. benthamiana proteins might share a common origin with AtMIK2 according to our phylogenetic analysis, they form a deviating cluster away from other Solanales proteins and do neither come back to AtMIK2 or tomato MIK2-clade proteins as top hit when reblasted against the respective proteomes. It is nevertheless possible that EnFOE actually triggers responses in wildtype Nicotiana benthamiana, which simply stay below our detection limit, since even elicitation with high concentrations of flg22 or chitin only induce comparably weak ROS responses in this plant species (fig. S1a-b).

Taken together, the demonstrated EnFOE-responsiveness in different plant species and our phylogenetic analysis raise the possibility of a conserved perception mechanism for the Fusarium elicitor involving proteins of the MIK2-clade across different plant orders.

sec.title: A MIK2-clade protein from Solanum lycopersicum shows similar properties to AtMIK2 in Fusarium elicitor perception
sec.p: Since genes of the MIK2-clade show a highly species-dependent pattern of gene duplication and retention (fig. 1e-f; fig. S1c), identification of a clear functional orthologue of AtMIK2 in terms of EnFOE perception was difficult merely based on the phylogenetic relation. Therefore, we tested all five proteins of the MIK2-clade as well as the protein from the MIK2-sister-clade from the Solanales species Solanum lycopersicum. Indeed, transient over-expression of the SlMIK2-A protein conferred EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana comparable to AtMIK2, while this was not the case for the other tomato proteins of the MIK2- or MIK2-sister-clade (fig. 2b). In line with the lack of responsiveness of Solanum lycopsericum to treatment with AtSCOOP12 and FocSCOOPL peptides (fig. 1b-d), neither of the tested tomato proteins were able to confer sensitivity to respective elicitors to Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. 2c; fig. S2a-b). These results further support the hypothesis of a conserved EnFOE perception mechanism that requires proteins of the MIK2-clade in different plant orders, whereas the perception of SCOOPs has evolved only in members of Brassicales (Snoeck et al., 2024).

Additional support that AtMIK2 and SlMIK2-A might derive from a common ancestor and hence share a conserved function in the perception of EnFOE, is provided by our synteny analysis (fig. 2d). Both receptor genes reside at a conserved genomic region in respective plant species. Interestingly, the syntenic locus in Solanum lycopersicum additionally harbors the genes coding for SlMIK2-B, -C and -D (fig. 2d), which are not able to confer EnFOE-sensitivity to N. benthamiana (fig. 2a). Intriguingly, the intracellular domain of SlMIK2-C is almost identical to that of SlMIK2-A, while its extracellular domain shows higher similarity to that of SlMIK2-B, potentially representing a product of recombination (Man et al., 2020). This is not the case for SlMIK2-D, which is overall more similar to SlMIK2-B (table S1).

Interestingly, SlMIK2-A is predicted to be spliced into 4 different variants, leading to variations in both the resulting ecto- and the kinase-domain (fig. 2e). In contrast, no comparable splice-variants that lead to alterations in the ectodomain are formed from AtMIK2. However, there are similarities between SlMIK2-A splice variant #3 and MIK2.2, both of which have a prolonged intron, resulting in shorter intracellular domains and sequence deviating c-termini. In both plant species, splice-variant #1 is predominantly expressed (fig. 2e; fig. S2e) (van der Does et al., 2017) and translated into functional proteins involved in the perception of EnFOE, as demonstrated by our gain-of-function assay in Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. 2f). It has already been demonstrated that alternative splicing plays an important role in the fine-tuning of plant immune responses (Kufel et al., 2022; Godinho et al., 2024). For example, in the absence of infection, the S-domain receptor-like kinase Nt-Sd-RLK from Nicotiana tabacum is spliced to produce a shorter variant, lacking a kinase domain. Upon stimulation of tobacco cells with lipopolysaccharides (LPS), the splicing pattern shifts to favor the expression of a longer, signaling-competent variant that includes an active kinase domain (Sanabria and Dubery, 2016).

The expression of PRRs like FLS2 and AtMIK2 has been shown to be transcriptionally upregulated after treatment with elicitors like flg22 or AtSCOOP12 (Hou et al., 2021; Zipfel et al., 2004). Similarly, the transcription of SlMIK2-A (splice-variant 1) is induced after treatment with EnFOE or chitin as well as by infection with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici strain Fol007 (fig. 2h). This upregulation of PRRs upon perception of MAMPs is thought to serve as a positive feedback mechanism to enhance perception capabilities (Boller and Felix, 2009). As expected for a signaling-competent LRR-RK, SlMIK2-A requires an active kinase domain to confer EnFOE-sensitivity to N. benthamiana and localizes to the plasma membrane (fig. 2f; 2i-j).

We could not confirm the function of SlMIK2-A observed in Nicotiana benthamiana by complementation assays in Arabidopsis thaliana mik2 mutants. Even though we tried to express the protein in different variations (genomic sequence, coding sequence, codon-optimized synthetic sequence, chimeric proteins with AtMIK2), with different tags (C-terminal cMyc, C-terminal GFP, N-terminal TwinStrep, untagged) and under the control of different promotors (p35S, pUBQ5, pAtMIK2), we did not obtain lines that stably expressed the protein of interest to a level detectable by western blot analysis (data not shown). This is reminiscent of problems with heterologous expression of SlFLS2 in Arabidopsis thaliana, which was speculated to be caused by failed recognition of the signal peptide or misfolding followed by subsequent discarding via ER-associated protein degradation (ERAD) (Robatzek et al., 2007). Taken together, with SlMIK2-A we identified a prime candidate for a MIK2 orthologue, which shares phylogenetic relations, a syntenic locus, a similar subcellular localization and EnFOE-related functions with AtMIK2.

sec.title: SlMIK2-A forms EnFOE-induced complexes with tomato BAK1 orthologues and depletes elicitor-activity from EnFOE
sec.p: For the perception of proteinaceous MAMPs like flg22 and elf18, respective PRRs commonly form ligand-induced complexes with members of the SERK family in Arabidopsis thaliana (Chinchilla et al., 2007; Roux et al., 2011; Heese et al., 2007) and similar mechanisms are in place in plants of other lineages (Peng and Kaloshian, 2014; Wei et al., 2020). Also treatment with SCOOP peptides and EnFOE induces the association between AtMIK2 with the coreceptor AtBAK1 (Coleman et al., 2021; Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021). Similar to AtMIK2 and AtBAK1, SlMIK2-A forms EnFOE-induced complexes with tomato BAK1 orthologues SlSERK3a or SlSERK3b when co-expressed in Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. 3a). In contrast, treatment with AtSCOOP12 or FocSCOOPLFOXB_11846 peptide does not trigger interactions between the tomato receptor pairs (fig. 3b, fig S3a). These results support an interaction between SlMIK2-A and EnFOE and further substantiate the existence of a conserved mechanism for the perception of the Fusarium elicitor in different plant orders.

An additional support for interaction between the elicitor-active molecule in EnFOE and the ectodomain of AtMIK2 and SlMIK2- A is provided by our specially adopted ligand-depletion assay (Shu et al., 2021). We filtered elicitor preparations through ectodomain-lined affinity columns and analyzed the flow-through for remaining AtMIK2-dependent elicitor activity (fig. 3c-e). Indeed, columns lined with eAtMIK2 or eSlMIK2-A fully depleted AtMIK2-dependent elicitor-activity from EnFOE flow-through (fig. 3d). These results also indicate that both ectodomains interact with the same elicitor molecules, since eSlMIK2-A depletes the activity that is subsequently triggering AtMIK2-dependent calcium-responses in Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings (fig. 3d). In line with all previous results, AtSCOOP12 is only depleted by the ectodomain of AtMIK2, while this is not the case for eSlMIK2-A (fig. 3e). The depleting activity of the AtMIK2 ectodomain in our assay also does not seem to be due to a high degree of unspecific binding capacity of the receptor, since flg22 preparations that passed the eAtMIK2-lined columns still harbored comparable AtFLS2-dependent elicitor activity to those run through columns lined with all other tested ectodomains (fig. 3f). Therefore, the depletion assay that we have adopted and customized specifically for our purpose seems to be a useful tool to gain first insights into receptor-ligand interactions. Even though there are quite a few elaborate in vitro analytical approaches available to study plant receptor-ligand interactions, those often require costly equipment as well as knowledge about identity and concentrations of both interaction partners (Sandoval and Santiago, 2020). In combination with a sensitive bio-assay for the reliable readout of ligand depletion, our assay provides a simple and relatively inexpensive method to study ligand-receptor interactions on a basic level, similar to a comparable method published before (Shu et al. 2021). Our assay might be especially useful if the molecular nature of the ligand is still unknown or is not available in a purified form, as is the case with EnFOE.

sec.title: SlMIK2-A is important for EnFOE-induced PTI responses and resistance against Fusarium oxysporum infection in tomato
sec.p: Comparable to Arabidopsis thaliana mik2 mutants, knock-out of SlMIK2-A led to reduced PTI responses to the enriched Fusarium oxysporum elicitor. However, in contrast to the basically full loss of responsiveness in Atmik2 mutants, Slmik2-A mutants still showed residual responses to EnFOE (Coleman et al., 2021) (fig. 4a; 4c). A possible explanation could be that the enrichment of EnFOE was initially optimized for Arabidopsis thaliana with the goal to eliminate all non-AtMIK2-dependent elicitor activity from the preparations. It therefore is possible that tomato is perceiving an additional elicitor molecule present in EnFOE that is not perceived by Arabidopsis thaliana, for example by a PRR that is not conserved between different plant families, as it is quite often the case (Zipfel et al., 2006; Ranf et al., 2015; Wang et al., 2016). It is also possible that a different epitope of the same elicitor is perceived by an additional receptor that is not phylogenetically related to MIK2, as is the case with tomato SlFLS2 and SlFLS3, which perceive different motifs of bacterial flagellin (Hind et al., 2016). Future efforts to identify the true nature and characteristics of the molecule in EnFOE that triggers MIK2-dependent PTI responses will help to answer this question. Even though none of the other tomato proteins of the MIK2-clade and MIK2-sister-clade were able to confer EnFOE-sensitivity to Nicotiana benthamiana (fig. 2b), we cannot finally exclude that they might also be involved in the perception of EnFOE in the native system.

Surprisingly, while we could not observe differences in chitin-triggered ROS production between Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants and the wildtype control (fig. 4b), the chitin-induced accumulation of ethylene was reduced in the mutants (fig. 4d). However, flg22-induced accumulation of ethylene was not compromised, showing that the mutants are not generally impaired in MAMP-induced ethylene responses (fig. 4e). Interestingly, also loss of AtMIK2 leads to reduced responses to certain other MAMPs like flg22 (Rhodes et al., 2021) and AtMIK2 has been proposed to serve as a scaffolding component for the coordination of perception events in Arabidopsis thaliana (Delplace et al., 2024). Potentially loss of SlMIK2-A has a similar effect on certain other PTI-signaling pathways and outputs in tomato. Nevertheless, these results demonstrate an important contribution of SlMIK2-A mainly to EnFOE-induced PTI responses in tomato.

The reduced ability of Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants to recognize and respond to a danger signal coming from Fusarium also translates into an enhanced susceptibility to infection with the pathogen (fig. 4f-g). We deliberately chose a strain of Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici (Fol007), which only mildly affects our wildtype control plants. It is known that Fol strains can actively interfere with and dampen PTI-signaling via the secretion of specialized effector proteins (Di et al., 2017; Tintor et al., 2020; Lamo et al., 2021; Blekemolen et al., 2023) and it was shown that the Avr2 effector from Fol affects PTI responses triggered by EnFOE when expressed in Arabidopsis thaliana (Coleman et al., 2021). Hence, if EnFOE-induced PTI is already partially shut down by the pathogen, the contribution a single involved RK has on overall resistance would most likely become small. Already without interference by pathogens, loss of a single PRR is sometimes not sufficient to cause alterations in resistance phenotypes, most likely due to the extensive arsenal of additional PRRs that perceive different MAMPs and act as an efficient backup system in the case of failure of one (Zipfel et al., 2004; Boller and Felix, 2009; Fan et al., 2022). Even in a natural setting plants can survive the loss of a single PRR, as demonstrated by the Arabidopsis thaliana ecotypes Ws-0 and Cvi-0, which carry natural loss-of-function mutations in the FLS2 receptor (Gómez-Gómez et al., 1999; Dunning et al., 2007). Interestingly, contributions of individual PRRs to overall resistance can also be diminished when the pathogens are supported to overcome the first layers of pre-invasive resistance, which was shown when bacteria are infiltrated in leaves rather than being sprayed on them (Zipfel et al., 2004). Nevertheless, even though we also assisted the Fol007 strain by damaging the root tissue of our tomato plants prior inoculation with the spores, we could observe a stronger negative impact of infection on plant growth in our Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants, with significantly enhanced reduction in plant height and fresh-weight when compared to the wildtype control (fig. 4f-g). This positive contribution of SlMIK2-A to tomato resistance towards Fusarium infection might potentially be even more pronounced in a natural setting with a largely undamaged root system. In the laboratory setting, however, we had to damage the roots prior to inoculation to obtain reproducible results.

We here present insights into the evolutionary trajectory of a multifunctional plant PRR. Arabidopsis MIK2 is perceiving the exceptionally large and diverse family of endogenous SCOOP peptides while simultaneously being involved in the recognition of a yet to be identified danger signal deriving from Fusarium and related fungi (Coleman et al., 2021; Hou et al., 2021; Rhodes et al., 2021; Snoeck et al., 2024).

There are a few examples of cell-surface receptors with dual ligands, including Arabidopsis CARD1/HPCA1 involved in the perception of quinone and H202 (Laohavisit et al., 2020; Wu et al., 2020), potato NILR1 perceiving the NAMP ascaroside and the endogenous plant hormone brassinosteroid (Huang et al., 2024; Huang et al., 2023, 2023; Huang et al., 2024) or the Arabidopsis RLP30 detecting SCP peptides from oomycetes and fungi as well as SCP-nonhomologous signals from bacteria (Yang et al., 2023b). Similar flexibility can also be observed for certain intracellular receptors which can perceive different microbial effector molecules (Brabham et al., 2024). On the other hand there are examples of single ligands that are perceived by multiple related receptors, like is the case for IDA and the LRR-RKs HAE and HSL2 (Butenko et al., 2014), for the PEP1 and PEP2 peptides and the LRR-RKs PEPR1 and PEPR2 (Huffaker et al., 2006; Yamaguchi et al., 2010), or with CEP4, which functions through the three LRR-RKs CEPR1, CEPR2 and RLK7, all of which show distinct patterns of tissue- and cell-specific expression (Rzemieniewski et al., 2024). It remains an interesting question, why AtMIK2 evolved the exclusive ability to function in the perception of the extraordinary large family of SCOOP peptides and the Fusarium elicitor, and why potential gene duplications that could facilitate the distribution of the work-load were not retained in most Brassicales. The fact that SCOOPs and their perception are restricted to members of Brassicales, while genes of the MIK2-clade and Fusarium elicitor-responsiveness are commonly found in angiosperms (fig. 1a-f) could suggest a more ancient role in the perception of the microbial signature while the function as receptor for the endogenous peptides has been gained later, either simultaneously or after the appearance of SCOOPs themselves. Situations where the perception of phytocytokines might have evolved through the molecular mimicry of microbial signatures has been proposed before (Ngou et al., 2024; Hou et al., 2021). Finally, it is also conceivable that SCOOPs initially evolved to serve different functions, for example as antimicrobial peptides. Such activities have been demonstrated for multiple SCOOPs, even before they were designated as such (Yadeta et al., 2014; Yu et al., 2020; Zhang et al., 2022; Neukermans et al., 2015; Zhang et al., 2022). One or multiple Brassicales-specific mutations on the ectodomain of MIK2 might then have given rise to the interaction with SCOOPs, while still retaining the initial function in perception of the Fusarium elicitor.

sec.title: Plant lines and growth conditions
sec.p: For ROS measurements in different plant species, Arabidopsis thaliana Col-0, Brassica rapa subsp. chinensis (Pak-Choi), Glycine max cv. Williams 82, Solanum lycopersicum cv. M82 and Hordeum vulgare cv. Golden Promise were planted in soil:vermiculite substrate (ratio 8:1), stratified for 2 days (dark; 4°C) and grown under long-day conditions (16 hours light : 8 hours dark photoperiod; 20 – 22°C [16°C for Hordeum vulgare]; 55% rel. hum.) for 6 – 8 weeks. Solanum lycopersicum CRISPR mutants and corresponding azygous wildtype control plants for ROS and ethylene measurements were grown for 8 – 12 weeks under the same conditions. Nicotiana benthamiana plants for ROS measurements and transient transformation were grown under long-day conditions as described above, but without stratification.

CRISPR-Cas9 mediated knock-out of AtMIK2 and SlMIK2-A was performed using apoaequorin-expressing A. thaliana Col-0AEQ (pMAQ2, Marc Knight, University of Durham, UK) or S. lycopersicum cv. M82 as starting material, respectively.

For measurement of aequorin luminescence, seeds of A. thaliana Col-0AEQ wildtype, mik2AEQ CRISPR and fls2-26AEQ (Ranf et al., 2012) mutants were surface-sterilized, stratified for 2 days (dark; 4°C) and grown under long-day conditions (16 hours light : 8 hours dark photoperiod; 22°C) in liquid medium (½ Murashige & Skoog medium plus vitamins [Duchefa, Haarlem, Netherlands], 2.5 g/L sucrose, 1 mM MES, pH 5.7) for 7 days.

For growth in a hydroponics system (Araponics, Liege, Belgium), seeds of S. lycopersicum cv. M82 wildtype were surface sterilized with chlorine gas, placed in seed-holders with solid medium (Murashige & Skoog medium plus vitamins [Duchefa, Haarlem, Netherlands], 1 g/L phytagel) and stratified for 2 days (dark, 4°C). Subsequently, seed-holders were placed in hydroponic boxes containing liquid ‘standard’ medium (Tocquin et al., 2003), covered with plastic lids and grown under long-day conditions as described above. Medium was replaced weekly and lids were removed two weeks after germination.

sec.title: Molecular cloning
sec.p: All genomic and coding sequences for transient over-expression in N. benthamiana were cloned into GoldenGate modules using appropriate primers and assembled to be expressed under the control of CaMV 35S promotor and terminator sequences. Gene cassettes were then ligated into a GoldenGate-modified pCB302 binary vector for plant expression. Cloned sequences and primers can be found in table S1. Proteins for gain-of-function assays, co-immunoprecipitation and confocal imaging experiments were fused to a C-terminal Myc, an enhanced monomeric GFP or a mCherry tag.

For the apoplastic expression of LRR ectodomains, sequences coding for the non-cytoplasmic domains were predicted (PHOBIUS; (Käll et al., 2004); https://phobius.sbc.su.se/index.html) and amplified using appropriate primers (table S1). All constructs were N-terminally fused to a TwinStrep affinity tag, c-terminally tagged with HA and placed behind the signal peptide of AtLORE (AT1G61380, AA 1-21) for reliable secretion.

For the generation of A. thaliana mik2 CRISPR/Cas9 mutants, two different target sites were chosen using the chopchop software tool (https://chopchop.cbu.uib.no/, table S1). Designed guide RNA constructs were synthesized (Twist Bioscience, San Francisco, USA) and stacked into a GoldenGate-adapted pUC18-based vector. Guide RNA stacks and FastRed-pRPS5::Cas9 were subsequently ligated into a pICSL4723 vector for plant expression.

For the cloning of constructs for CRISPR/Cas9 mediated knock-out of SlMIK2-A, two different target sites were chosen using the chopchop software tool (https://chopchop.cbu.uib.no/, table S1). Chosen guide RNA (gRNA) sequences were synthesized (Twist Bioscience, San Francisco, USA) and stacked with respective gRNA scaffolds in a GoldenGate-adapted entry vector. Guide RNA stacks were subsequently ligated into a CRISPR-optimized vector containing pSlUBQ10::Cas9 and kanamycin resistance marker for plant expression.

sec.title: Elicitors
sec.p: Enriched Fusarium oxysporum elicitor (EnFOE) fractions were prepared as described before (Coleman et al., 2021). Concentrations refer to μg total protein per mL. Shrimp shell-derived chitin (Cat no : C9752, Sigma-Aldrich, Taufkirchen, Germany) was ground to fine powder and extracted with ddH2O overnight at 4°C on a rotator. Concentrations refer to μg chitin powder that was resolved per mL of water before extraction. The flg22 peptide (QRLSTGSRINSAKDDAAGLQIA) was synthesized on an Abimed EPS221 system (Abimed, Langenfeld, Germany). AtSCOOP12 (PVRSSQSSQAGGR), FocSCOOPLFOXB_11846 (ESSSSHSERAGGR) and FocSCOOPLF9F6H0 (YVQGSHSSHTGGR) from F. oxysporum f.sp. conglutinans (strain Fo5176) were ordered from Pepmic Corp. Ltd (Suzhou, China).

sec.title: Detection of ROS accumulation
sec.p: Leaf discs (ø 4 mm) from 6-8-week-old soil grown plants were floated on 200 μL ddH2O for 6 hours (transiently transformed N. benthamiana) or overnight (all other plant species) in white 96-well plates (RT, dark). Water was replaced by 75 μL substrate consisting of 2 μg/mL type II horseradish peroxidase (Roche, Grenzach-Wyhlen, Germany) and 5 μM L-012 (WAKO Chemicals, Neuss, Germany). Emitted luminescence was recorded as relative light units (rlu) at 1 min intervals with a Tecan F200 (Tecan, Männersdorf, Switzerland) or a HRPCS5 Camera system (Photek, St. Leonards, UK). Measurements consisted of 10 mins background reading followed by 60-120 mins after elicitor treatment. Values were normalized to average background luminescence followed by subtraction of values for mock-treated samples (included for each genotype on each plate). Normalized values of individual leaf discs were summarized over the whole measurement after elicitor treatment and are presented as cumulative (cum.) ROS.

sec.title: Phylogenetic analysis
sec.p: Sequences of full length proteins with similarity to AtMIK2 of Amborella trichopoda, Aquilegia coerulea, Arabidopsis lyrate, Arabidopsis thaliana, Arachis hypogea, Boechera strictum, Brachipodium distachyon, Brassica oleracea, Brassica rapa, Capsella grandiflora, Capsella rubella, Cicer arietinum, Cleome violacea, Curcumis sativum, Eschscholzia californica, Euclidium syriacum, Ginkgo biloba, Glycine max, Helianthus annuus, Hordeum vulgare, Lens culinaris, Lepidum sativum, Lupinus albus, Manihot esculenta, Medicago truncatula, Nymphaea colorata, Olea europaea, Oryza sativa, Phaseolus vulgaris, Salix purpurea, Schrenkinella parvula, Solanum lycopersicum, Solanum tuberosum, Sorghum bicolor, Theobroma cacao, Thlapsi arvense, Trifolium pretense, Vitis vinifera and Zea mays were acquired using BLAST (Altschul et al., 1990) from Phytozome (https://phytozome-next.jgi.doe.gov/; (Goodstein et al., 2012)or NCBI (https://blast.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/) for Nicotiana benthamiana, Nicotiana tabacum and Solanum chilense. A search for MIK2-clade genes in bryophytes, lycophytes and monilophytes using the ICIPS-garden BLAST server (http://134.176.27.173/blast/; (Roessner et al., 2024) remained without results. The sequences were aligned using MAFFT (Katoh et al., 2002). A Maximum-likelihood phylogeny was generated using IQ-TREE2 (Minh et al., 2020) with 100 bootstraps. All computing was carried out using de.NBI VM large (28 VCPUs, 64 GB RAM). Sequences used for the analysis and gene copy numbers can be found in table S1.

sec.title: Synteny analysis
sec.p: A locus analysis was performed for the MIK2-clade locus of S. lycopersicum v3.2 and A. thaliana ARAPORT11 as described before (Snoeck et al., 2024). In short, BLASTP (BLAST 2.9.0+, e-value 10) was used to identify the syntenic loci by mining the genomes initially for homologues of the strongly conserved neighbor genes of Arabidopsis MIK2 (AT4G08850); AT4G08840 and AT4G08920. Subsequently, putative MIK2-clade proteins were identified using BLASTP, resulting in a list of four SlMIK2-clade genes named A, B, C and D. Locus comparison was performed using R (v4.0.3) and the R-package genoPlotR (v0.8.11) using the extracted contiguous MIK2-clade loci and their corresponding annotation. The resulting figure was edited in Corel-DRAW Home & Student x7.

sec.title: Aequorin luminescence measurements
sec.p: 7-day-old liquid-grown apoaequorin-expressing Arabidopsis thaliana seedlings were individually incubated in 96-well plates containing 100 μL of 5 μM coelenterazine-h solution (PJK, Kleinblittersdorf, Germany) overnight (RT, dark). Luminescence was recorded as relative light units (rlu) with a Luminokan Ascent 2.1 luminometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Dreieich, Germany). Each well was scanned 12 times at 10 sec intervals to determine background luminescence intensities, followed by 180 measurements in 10 sec intervals after treatment with elicitor solutions. Remaining aequorin was discharged by addition of 150 μL discharge solution (2 M CaCl2, 20 % ethanol) per well. Cytosolic calcium ion concentrations ([Ca2+]cyt) were calculated as luminescence counts per second relative to total luminescence counts remaining (L/Lmax) as previously described (Ranf et al., 2012). Normalized values of individual seedlings were summarized over the whole measurements after elicitor treatment and are presented as cumulative (cum.) [Ca2+]cyt.

sec.title: Ethylene measurements
sec.p: For the measurement of ethylene accumulation after elicitor treatment, leaf discs (ø 4 mm) from youngest fully developed leaves of 8 – 12-week-old S. lycopersicum plants were floated on ddH2O overnight (RT, dark). The next day, for each sample 3 leaf discs were transferred to 5 mL glass vials containing 100 μL ddH2O and 50 μL elicitor or mock solution were added to indicated final concentrations. Vials were sealed airtight with rubber lids and incubated under gentle agitation for 4.5 hours. After incubation, 1 mL of air was sampled from the headspace with a 1 mL syringe and injected into a Varian 3300 gas chromatograph (Waters Corporation, Milford, USA) equipped with a 1 m long AlO3 column. Detector was set to 225°C, injector and column to 80°C and ethylene was separated from the sample using O2, H2 and N2 at 0.5 MPa. Amount of ethylene was calculated using a method based on the area under the curve as described before (Kruedener et al., 1995).

sec.title: Gene-expression analysis
sec.p: For the analysis of elicitor-induced changes in gene-expression, 4-week-old hydroponically grown S. lycopersicum plants (azygous wildtype control) were submerged in mock or elicitor solutions in the indicated concentrations for 2 hours. Subsequently, whole plants were frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground to fine powder using mortar and pestle. For the analysis of Fol007-induced changes in gene-expression, 3 randomly chosen mock and Fol007-infected azygous wildtype control plants from 5 infection experiment (fig. 4f-f) were frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground to fine powder with mortar and pestle. For the analysis of SlMIK2-A splice-variant abundance, 10 leaf discs (ø4 mm) from youngest fully developed leaves of 8 – 12-week-old S. lycopersicum plants (azygous wildtype control) were frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground to fine powder using a tissue lyzer. RNA was isolated from 3 g powder or 10 ground leaf discs using TRIzol reagent (Roche, Switzerland) and the Direct-zol™ RNA Miniprep Plus kit (Zymo Research, Germany). Synthesis of cDNA including DNaseI treatment was performed for 2 μg total RNA using the ReverseAid kit with random hexamer primers according to manufacturer (Cat No : K1621, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Germany). Real-time qPCR was performed using Takyon Low ROX SYBR (Eurogentec, Belgium) with a AriaMx Real-Time PCR system (Agilent Technologies, USA). Expression levels of target genes were calculated using the 2–ΔΔCT method (Livak and Schmittgen, 2001) and normalized to the tomato house-keeping gene SlEF1α (Solyc06g009970). For analysis, mean values from two technical replicates for each primer-sample combination were calculated. Data represent expression of target genes in elicitor- or Fol007-treated samples compared to respective mock-treated controls. Expression of individual SlMIK2-A splice-variants represents expression relative to the predominant splice-variant 1. Transcript-specific primer sequences used in the analysis can be found in table S1.

sec.title: Stable transformation of Arabidopsis thaliana and Solanum lycopersicum
sec.p: For the generation of the A. thaliana mik2 CRISPR mutant, wildtype apoaequorin-expression Col-0 plants (pMAQ2) were transformed with Agrobacteria (strain GV3101) carrying plasmids with respective constructs (see ‘Molecular cloning’) by the floral-dip method. Homozygous knock-out mutation was confirmed in the T2 generation by PCR and sequencing and T-DNA was segregated out using the FastRed marker as visual aid. Schematics of induced mutations are shown in fig. S3.

Generation of tomato (cv. M82) Slmik2-ACRISPR mutants and the azygous wildtype control (construct lacking guide RNAs) was performed under sterile conditions using Agrobacteria (strain GV3101) carrying respective constructs (see ‘Molecular cloning’). Transformation of cotyledons, followed by callus formation and regeneration of transgenic plants was performed as described before (Wittmann et al., 2016). Homozygous mutations were confirmed in the T2 generation by PCR and sequencing. Removal of T-DNA though segregation in subsequent generations was confirmed by PCR. A potential off-target (with 3 mismatches) of one of the guide RNAs (Target 2, table S1) in the sequence of the receptor-like protein Cf-9 (LOC101255572) was confirmed as non-mutated by PCR and sequencing in all the lines. Schematics of induced mutations in SlMIK2-A are shown in fig. S4.

sec.title: Agrobacteria-mediated transient transformation of Nicotiana benthamiana
sec.p: Chemically competent Agrobacteria (strain GV3101) were transformed with desired constructs and selected on YEB plates (5 g/L beef extract, 1 g/L yeast extract, 5 g/L peptone, 5 g/L sucrose, 0.3 g/L MgSO4, 20 g/L agar-agar) containing appropriate antibiotics (10 μg/mL rifampicin, 30 μg/mL gentamicin, 50 μg/mL kanamycin) for 3 days at 28°C. For the preculture, selected colonies were inoculated in 3 mL low-salt LB medium (10 g/L peptone, 5 g/L yeast extract, 5 g/L NaCl) supplemented with 30 μg/mL gentamicin and 50 μg/mL kanamycin for 24 hours at 28°C with 180 rpm on a shaker. The next day, desired amounts of bacterial growth medium (10 g/L peptone, 10 g/L yeast extract, 5 g/L NaCl) supplemented with 30 μg/mL gentamicin, 50 μg/mL kanamycin and 20 μM acetosyringone (Cat no : D134406, Sigma-Aldrich, Taufkirchen, Germany) were inoculated with 10 μL/mL of fully grown subculture and incubated for 24 hours at 28°C with 180 rpm on a shaker. Agrobacteria were harvested by centrifugation (2,500xg, 5 min, RT) and washed with infiltration buffer (10 mM MES pH 5.8, 10 mM MgCl2, 20 μM acetosyringone). Finally, bacteria were resolved to OD600 of 1.0 in infiltration buffer and mixed in a 1:1 ratio with bacteria carrying plasmids for transformation with the p19 silencing suppressor (Voinnet et al., 2003). Bacterial suspensions were infiltrated into youngest fully-expanded leaves of 6 – 8-week-old N. benthamiana plants with a needleless syringe. After infiltration, plants were placed back to the growth chamber for 36 hours.

sec.title: Immunoblotting
sec.p: Proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE using a 8% resolving gel and blotted onto PVDF membranes (supplier) using a wet-transfer system (Cat no : 1703930, Bio-Rad Laboratories, Feldkirchen, Germany). Membranes were blocked with 5 % milk in Phosphate-Buffered Saline (PBS) buffer for 2 hours, washed with PBS-T buffer (0.05% Tween20) and incubated with primary antibodies in 10% milk in PBS-T overnight at 4°C. Membranes were washed with PBS-T (3 x 10 min) and incubated with secondary antibodies in 5% milk in PBS-T for 2 hours at RT. Subsequently, membranes were washed with PBS-T (3 x 10 min), placed in SuperSignal West Dura substrate (Thermo Fisher Scientific, Dreieich, Germany) and visualized using a Fusion SL Imager (Vilber Lourmat, Eberhardzell, Germany) with the accompanying software. Coomassie brilliant blue or Ponceau S staining was performed to confirm equal protein loading and blotting.

sec.title: Ligand-depletion assay
sec.p: Apoplastic expression of LRR ectodomains and ligand depletion assay were adopted from (Laohavisit et al., 2020; Shu et al., 2021; Ishihama et al., 2022) N. benthamiana leaves were transformed with constructs designed to transiently overexpress apoplast-targeted, TwinStrep-tagged ectodomains of different LRR-RLKs (see ‘Molecular cloning’) via infiltration with Agrobacteria as described above. 3 days after transformation, leaves were vacuum-infiltrated with cold buffer (20 mM Tris-HCl, pH 7.8), carefully dried with paper towels and rolled around 1 mL pipette tips. Tips were positioned in empty 20 mL plastic syringes, which in turn were placed in 50 mL centrifugation tubes. Apolastic wash fluids (AWFs) were then collected via centrifugation (5,000xg, 10 mins, 4°C) and frozen at -20°C until further processing.

For the ligand depletion assay, ectodomain-containing AWFs were thawed on ice, centrifuged (13,000xg, 10 mins, 4°C) and 6 mL of supernatant was run through Strep-Tactin® 4Flow® high capacity columns (Cat no : 2-1251-005, IBA Life Sciences, Göttingen, Germany). Residual AWFs were washed out with 2 mL 1x Buffer W (Cat no : 2-1003-100, IBA Life Sciences) and columns were equilibrated with 1 mL BSA solution (1 mg/mL). Elicitor preparations were diluted in BSA solution (1 mg/mL) to desired concentrations and run through the ectodomain-lined columns in 200 μL portions in 3 subsequent steps. The last 200 μL portion was eluted with 200 μL BSA solution (1 mg/mL). All three eluted portions were collected individually and frozen until further processing. To account for initial unspecific binding, only the 3rd portion was used for analysis of remaining elicitor activity in the subsequent Ca2+-bioassays (see ‘Aequorin luminescence measurements’) and is referred to as ‘unbound fraction’. Finally, ectodomains were eluted with 500 μL 1 x Buffer E (Cat no : 2-1000-025, IBA Life Sciences), boiled in SDS-sample buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 6.8, 1% β-Mercaptoethanol, 2% SDS, 0.1% bromophenol blue, 10% glycerol) and ectodomain abundance was visualized by immunoblotting using TwinStrep-tag specific antibodies (Cat no : 2-1507-001, IBA Life Sciences).

sec.title: Co-Immunoprecipitation
sec.p: Interactors of interest (see ‘Molecular cloning’) were transiently co-expressed in N. benthamiana as described above. Agrobacteria suspensions were prepared to an overall OD600 of 1.0 in a 1:1:1 ratio (interactor 1 : interactor 2 : p19 silencing suppressor). 36 hours after Agro-infiltration, elicitor solutions were diluted to desired concentrations in ddH2O and infiltrated into one half of transformed leaves using a needleless syringe, the second half of each leaf was infiltrated with ddH2O as mock treatment. 20 mins after infiltration of elicitor solutions, 70 leaf discs (ø 4 mm) per combination were harvested in 2 mL tubes containing glass pearls, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground to fine powder using a tissue lyzer. Powder was resolved in 700 μL protein extraction buffer (50 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.5, 150 mM NaCl, 10% glycerol, 0.5% NP-40, 1 mM EDTA, 1% PVPP, 1% protease inhibitor cocktail, 1 mM PMSF, 10 mM DTT) and tubes were rotated at 4°C for 30 mins. After extraction, samples were diluted with 700 μL wash buffer (like extraction buffer, but with only 0.1% NP-40 and without PVPP), centrifuged (13,000xg, 15 min, 4°C) and supernatants were transferred to fresh tubes. 100 μL input aliquots were boiled in SDS-sample buffer and remaining supernatant was added to 1.5 mL tubes containing 15 μL of GFP-trap slurry (GFP-Trap® Agarose, Cat no : gta, ChromoTek GmbH, Planegg-Martinsried, Germany) that was washed and equilibrated with wash buffer beforehand. Subsequently, samples were rotated for 3 hours at 4°C, supernatant was removed, GFP-trap washed 4 times with 400 μL wash buffer and boiled in SDS-sample buffer. GFP- and Myc-tagged fusion proteins were visualized by immunoblotting using anti-GFP and anti-Myc antibodies (Cat no : 3h9 and 9E1, ChromoTek GmbH, Planegg-Martinsried, Germany).

sec.title: Gain-of-function assay in Nicotiana benthamiana
sec.p: Proteins of interest (see ‘Molecular cloning’) were transiently over-expressed in N. benthamiana as described above. 36 hours post infiltration, leaf discs (ø 4 mm) were taken for ROS measurements and protein extraction. Accumulation of reactive oxygen species was measured 6 hours after leaf disc excision as described above. Samples for protein extraction were placed in 2 mL tubes with glass pearls, snap-frozen in liquid nitrogen and ground to fine powder with a tissue lyzer. Powder was resolved in protein extraction buffer (see ‘Co-Immunoprecipitation’, 20 μL /leaf disc) and rotated at 4°C for 30 mins. Samples were centrifuged (13,000xg, 15 min, 4°C) and supernatant boiled in SDS-sample buffer. Myc-tagged fusion proteins were visualized by immunoblotting using anti-Myc antibodies (as above).

sec.title: Confocal microscopy
sec.p: To visualize subcellular localization of receptors of interest, fluorescently labelled AtMIK2-GFP and SlMIK2-A-mCherry (see ‘Molecular Cloning’) were transiently over-expressed in N. benthamiana as described above in a 1:1:1 ratio with silencing suppressor p19. Laser-scanning microscopy pictures were obtained using a Leica TCS SP5 system (Leica, Wetzlar, Germany). Imaging was performed with a 20 x water immersion objective. For the detection of GFP fluorescence, an argon laser with emission wavelength of 488 nm was used and the signal was detected from 500 – 550 nm with a HyD detector. The fluorescence of mCherry was excited with a DPSS 561 laser emitting at 561 nm and detected at 570 – 620 nm.

sec.title: Fusarium oxysporum infection assays
sec.p: Root-dip method was adapted from (Mes et al., 1999). F. oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici strain Fol007 was kindly provided by Frank L. W. Takken, University of Amsterdam. Tomato seeds were planted in sieved soil, stratified for 7 days (dark, 4°C) and grown under long-day conditions (8 h : 16 h, light : dark photoperiod, 20 – 22°C, 55% RH) for 14 days before infection. Fungal strain Fol007 was grown on potato extract glucose agar (PDA) plates for 14 days (RT, 16h light). Agar-plugs of fully gown fungal plates were placed in sporulation medium (30 g/L sucrose, 1.7 g/L yeast nitrogen base, 10 g/L KNO3, autoclaved) and incubated for 4 days (dark, 28°C, 180 rpm). Fungal spores were harvested by filtration and centrifugation, washed 3 times and resuspended to a concentration of 25 mio spores/mL in sterile water. 2-week-old tomato seedlings were uprooted from the soil, roots were equalized to 1 cm length with a scalpel and dipped into spore or mock (sterile water) solution for 10 mins. Infected seedlings were repotted individually in sieved soil and grown for 3 additional weeks under the same conditions. For subsequent evaluation, above ground tissues of tomato plants were cut with a scalpel at soil level, fresh-weight was taken with a scale and plant height was measured with a ruler from the bottom to the meristem of the main stem. Individual values of Fusarium infected plants were normalized to mean values of mock-treated plants for each genotype and calculated as % fresh-weight and % plant height relative to mock.

sec.title: Statistical analysis
sec.p: Statistical analyses (ordinary one-way ANOVA with Tukey’s multiple comparisons test) were performed using PRISM 8.0.1 (GraphPad Software, San Diego, USA). Different lowercase letters indicate statistical differences (adjusted P Value < 0.05).

caption.title: Elicitor-induced PTI responses and Fusarium oxysporum susceptibility of tomato Slmik2-A mutants.
caption.p: (a-b) Accumulation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) measured in leaf discs of two independent Solanum lycopersicum Slmik2-A CRISPR knock-out mutants (line #1 blue triangles, line #2 red squares) and the corresponding azygous wildtype control (gray dots) after elicitation with an enriched elicitor fraction from Fusarium oxysporum (EnFOE; 0.5 μg/mL) or chitin (50 μg/mL). Recorded values were normalized to mock-treated samples and summed up over a period of 120 mins (cum. ROS) and are given in relative light units (rlu). Data is pooled from 3 independent experiments, each with n = 8-16, bars indicate mean and standard deviation. Letters show significant differences (one-way ANOVA, Tukey’s test, ρ < 0.0004). (c-e) Ethylene concentration emitted from leaf discs of genotypes stated in a-b, 3.5 h after treatment with EnFOE (0.5 μg/mL), chitin (500 μg/mL) or flg22 (1 μM). Values were normalized to water (mock) treated samples. Data is pooled from 4 independent experiments, each with n = 4, bars indicate mean and standard deviation. Letters indicate significant differences (one-way ANOVA, Tukey’s test, ρ < 0.001). (f-g) Relative changes in fresh-weight and plant height of indicated tomato genotypes caused by 21 days of infection with Fusarium oxysporum f.sp. lycopersici (strain Fol007). Values were calculated relative to the average of respective mock-treated plants (100%) (left panels). Fresh-weight (in g) and plant height (in cm) of mock-treated plants included in the experiments are shown in the right panels. Data is pooled from 6 independent experiments, each with n = 5-15, bars show mean and standard deviation. Letters indicate significant differences within each panel (one-way ANOVA, Tukey’s test, ρ < 0.03).
